questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair of intercellular connections and their structural units
questions.solution:
Gap junctions are made of connexons. Connexons are in turn made of units called connexins.

The different intercellular connections and their structural units are given below:

Intercellular connections Structural units
Tight junctions or zona occludens Occludins, claudins and junctional adhesion molecules
Gap junctions Connexons
Zona adherens Cadherins
Desmosome Cadherins like desmoglein
Hemidesmosome Integrins

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man has been prescribed empagliflozin. Which of the following processes will most likely be affected by this drug?
questions.solution:
Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor. SGLT-2 or sodium-glucose transport protein 2 is an example of a cotransporter that plays a key role in glucose absorption from renal tubule by secondary active transport. This process is blocked by SGLT-2 inhibitors, leading to renal loss of glucose and improved glycemic control.

  • A special property of the transport protein involved in secondary active transport is that a conformational change to allow Na+ movement to the interior will not occur until a glucose molecule also attaches to the transport protein. When they both become attached, the conformational change takes place automatically, and the Na+ and glucose are transported to the inside of the cell at the same time.
  • The figure shows glucose is transported uphill and Na+ is transported downhill. Energy derived from the downhill movement of Na+ is maintained by the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral side.

questions.text: Receptors on cell membrane that activate ion channel after binding with agonists are_____
questions.solution:
Nicotinic cholinergic receptors activate an ion channel after binding with its agonist. These receptors are called ligand-gated channels or ionotropic receptors.

Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and function. They are:

  • Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in ionic conductance.
    • Important for fast synaptic transmission.
    • Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype).
  • G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated channels on neuronal membranes.
    • Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 5HT3) and opioid receptors.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential of a nerve fibre depends on ______
questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a nerve fibre depends on the diffusion of both K+ and Na+ and the Na+-K+ ATPase pump.

The most predominant factor, however, is the diffusion of K+ ions. This is because, at rest, the permeability of the membrane of the nerve fibre to K+ ions is almost 100 times greater than that to Na+. 

Related Pearl: Resting membrane potential (RMP) in tissues

Tissue

RMP(mV)

Neuron

-70

Skeletal muscle

-90

Myocardial muscle

-90

Smooth muscle

-20 to -65

questions.text: Normal osmolarity of plasma is mainly due to ________.
questions.solution:
Normal plasma osmolarity (~290 mOsm/L) is mainly due to Na+ and its accompanying anions, principally Cl- and HCO3-

  • Osmolarity (mOsm/L) = 2 [Na+] (mEq/L) + 0.055 [Glucose] (mg/dL) + 0.36 [BUN] (mg/dL)
  • Because sodium and its associated anions (Cl- , HCO3- ) account for about 94 per cent of the solute in the extracellular compartment, plasma osmolarity (Posm) can be roughly approximated as
    • Posm = 2.1 x Plasma sodium concentration
  • With a plasma sodium concentration of 142 mEq/L, the plasma osmolarity would be estimated from the formula above to be about 298 mOsm/L.
  • In conditions associated with renal disease, the contribution of two other solutes, glucose and urea, should be included.
  • Because urea easily permeates most cell membranes, it exerts little effective osmotic pressure under steady-state conditions. (Ineffective osmoles)
  • Contribution to plasma osmolarity:
    • Na+ and associated anions: 270 mOsm/L
    • Glucose : 5 mOsm/L
    • Urea: 5 mOsm/L
    • Plasma proteins: 2 mOsm/L
    • Other ions: 8 mOsm/L

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?

choices.text: B  fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.solution:
The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve. It leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact. A-fibers (includes the motor fibers) are affected.

The susceptibility of the nerve fibers to pressure is A>B>C.

This is responsible for Saturday night or Sunday morning paralysis.

Related Pearl: Relative susceptibility of nerve fibres to conduction block by various agents

Susceptibility

Intermediate

Least susceptible

Local anaesthetic

C

B

A

Hypoxia

B

A

C

Pressure

A

B

C

 

Controversial: There is a difference in the opinion quoted by various standard textbooks and authors.

According to Katzung pharmacology 14th edition page no. 465,  B=C > A delta > A gamma > A beta > A alpha

Ganong's Physiology 26th edition, page no. 92, Nerve fibre most susceptible to local anesthetics is C > B > A

Hence, the correct answer would solely depend on the reference book the examiner referred to while making the question.

questions.text: All of the following are true about excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle except that _____

choices.text: Acetylcholine is released at the nerve terminal.
Ca2+ is released from sarcoplasmic reticulum during contraction.
Ca2+ is pumped back into sarcoplasmic reticulum during relaxation.
Ca2+ binds to tropomyosin to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.solution: Ca2+ binds to troponin C (not tropomyosin) to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following endogenous opioids is correctly matched with the receptor at which it has maximum potency?
questions.solution:
Enkephalins have maximum potency at δ receptors.

Dynorphins have maximum potency at κ receptors.

Endorphins have maximum potency at μ receptors.

Note: There is a difference of opinion among Goodman & Gillman's textbook and Ganong’s review of medical physiology(26th edition pg 151). According to Goodman & Gillman's textbook above answer is correct.

Related Pearl: Opioid Receptors

Receptor

Effect

μ

Miosis

Urine retention

Sedation

Slowed GI transit - constipation

Supraspinal and spinal analgesia

Respiratory depression

Muscular rigidity

Euphoria 

Modulation of hormone and neurotransmitter release

δ

Supraspinal and spinal analgesia 

Modulation of hormone
and neurotransmitter release

κ

Slowed GI transit - constipation

Supraspinal and spinal analgesia

Psychotomimetic effect- Dysphoria

questions.text: Ejection fraction is
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction is SV/EDV.
The amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per stroke at rest is 70–90 mL. The end-diastolic ventricular volume is about 130 mL. The ejection fraction is the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke, is about 65%.

questions.text: Cardiac output measured by thermodilution method is unreliable in all of the following situations except?
questions.solution:
Thermodilution Method

  • It is based on the principle of the indicator dilution technique. the indicator used is cold saline.
  • The saline is injected into right atrium through , and the temperature change in the blood is recorded in the pulmonary artery. The temperature change is inversely proportional to the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary artery; that is, to the extent that the cold saline is diluted by blood.
  • A curve of the concentration (C ) is recorded as a function of time (t) as shown in the figure

The cardiac output can be then calculated by using the formula

CO = Cardiac output

E = amount of indicator injected

C = instantaneous concentration of indicator in arterial blood which is given by area under the curve

The thermodilution method is however not reliable in certain conditions.

Among the options provided in the question

VSD

  • Intracardiac shunts produce falsely high thermodilution cardiac output measurements.

TR

  • Tricuspid regurgitation causes the cold indicator fluid to be recycled back and forth across the tricuspid valve.

Low cardiac output

  • When the cardiac output is low more time is required for the temperature to return to the baseline producing a large area under the curve (Note-this is the best option one can choose although even in this case it is unreliable!).

PR

  • This is similar to TR where the pulmonary backflow causes an incorrect low value of cardiac output.

Other causes of inaccuracy in thermodilution method

  • Catheter in the wrong position
  • Thermistor tip is up against the wall
  • Respiration is erratic
  • Intracardiac shunt
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Abnormal hematocrit
  • Slow delivery of injectate
  • Injectate not cold enough

questions.text: Cerebral blood flow is regulated by all except _______
questions.solution:
Normal cerebral blood flow is maintained despite the fluctuations in blood pressure due to autoregulation.

Cerebral Blood Flow:

  • Normal cerebral blood flow→ 50-65mL/100g of brain tissue/min
  • For entire brain CBF→750-900mL/min (15% of the resting cardiac output)
  • Factors that increase CBF
    • Cerebral metabolic rate
    • ↑ Arterial Pco2
  • 70% increase in Paco2 (80mmHg)  approximately doubles the CBF
    • ↑ H+ ion concentration
    • Hypoxia
    • Substances released from astrocytes that cause local vasodilation- NO, K+, adenosine, etc

Role of intracranial pressure

  • Monro-Kellie doctrine 
    • Because brain tissue and spinal fluid are essentially incompressible, the volume of blood, spinal fluid, and brain in the cranium at any time must be constant
    • More importantly, cerebral vessels are compressed when intracranial pressure rises
    • Any change in venous pressure promptly causes a similar change in intracranial pressure

Related Pearl: Blood Pressure and its determinants

Type of Blood Pressure

Determinant

Systolic BP (SBP)

Stroke volume (directly proportional)

Compliance of aorta (inversely proportional)

Diastolic BP (DBP)

Elastic recoil of aorta/major vessels (directly proportional)

Pulse pressure (PP)

Ratio of stroke volume to compliance of the arterial tree

Mean blood pressure (MAP)

Cardiac output

Total peripheral resistance

questions.text: What is the partial pressure of O2 in the alveolus?
questions.solution:
The partial pressure of O2 in the alveolus is 100 mmHg.

The partial pressure of gases as they enter and leave the lungs is depicted below.

questions.text: Hering-Breuer reflexes are mediated by ____________ .
questions.solution:
Hering-Breuer reflexes are mediated by slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers.

Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: "Prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration"

  • Hyperinflation of lungs stimulates slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers.
  • This signal inhibits the inspiratory ramp signals of the dorsal respiratory group of neurons (DRG), thus, inspiration is quickly inhibited and expiration follows.
  • Advantages of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: It cuts down the inspiration time, and therefore,
    • It prevents overinflation of the lungs.
    • Lungs operate at lower lung volumes, thereby preventing wastage of energy.
  • The Hering-Breuer reflex is activated when the lung volume increases to more than three times the normal tidal volume (tidal volume = 0.5 liters/breath; So, lung volume > 1.5 liters per breath activates the reflex).
  • It signifies that the reflex plays a protective role preventing the overinflation of the lung rather than regulating the normal ventilation.

questions.text: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm H20)?
questions.solution:
Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure.

  • C= ΔV/ΔP

In this case,

ΔV= 1000 mL

ΔP= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O

The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration

Therefore the compliance is,

C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.text: Tidal volume is_____

choices.text: Inspiratory capacity minus inspiratory reserve volume
Total lung capacity minus residual volume
Functional residual capacity minus residual volume
Vital capacity minus expiratory reserve volume

questions.solution:
The tidal volume = inspiratory capacity - inspiratory reserve volume.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Photoreceptors - rods and cones are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.

End of controversy! The latest edition of Yanoff & Duker, mentions the photo-receptors as the first order neurons.

Related Pearl: Order of neurons in the visual pathway

Order of neurons in the visual pathway

First-order neurons

Photoreceptors
(rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Third-order neurons

Ganglion cells
(optic nerve)

Fourth-order neurons

Axons from the lateral geniculate body
(optic radiation)

questions.text: Setting posture before planned movement is associated with ____.
questions.solution:
• The premotor cortex may be concerned with a setting posture at the start of a planned movement and getting the individual prepared to move. It is most involved in control of proximal limb muscles needed to orient the body for movement.
  • It is located anterior to the precentral gyrus, on the lateral and medial cortical surface; it also con­tains a somatotopic map almost identical to the topographic organization in primary motor cortex with the mouth and face areas located most laterally. As one moves upward, the hand, arm, trunk, and leg areas are encountered. (as seen in the figure below)
  • This region receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex and projects to primary motor cortex (M1), the spinal cord, and the brainstem reticular formation.
  • A special class of neurons called mirror neurons becomes active when a person performs a specific motor task or when he or she observes the same task performed by others. These neurons transform sensory representations of acts that are heard or seen into motor representations of these acts.

questions.text: Salivary amylase is activated by which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
Salivary amylase is activated by Cl-.

Human salivary and pancreatic amylases are activated by chloride (Cl–). They have optimum activities near-neutral pH (7.4). They hydrolyze internal 1:4α linkages but spare 1:6α linkages and terminal 1:4α linkages in starch.

questions.text: Sodium-iodide symport is absent in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Sodium-iodide symport is absent in the pituitary.

Na+/I– symporter is present in

  • Basolateral membranes of thyrocytes facing the capillar­ies.
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands

questions.text: Which of the following provides a negative feedback in spermatogenesis?
questions.solution:
Negative feedback in spermatogenesis is by inhibin.

FSH stimulates inhibin production by the Sertoli cells. This inhibin inhibits FSH production by directly acting on the anterior pituitary. 

LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH. Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus.

questions.text: Which of these cause hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Calcitonin has calcium-lowering effects and may cause hypocalcemia. It does so by inhibiting bone resorption (direct effect)

Calcitonin is synthesized and secreted by parafollicular (clear) cells of the thyroid. Actions of calcitonin are as follows:

  • Inhibits osteoclasts, thereby decreasing bone resorption (direct effect)
  • Increases renal calcium excretion
  • Decreases calcium absorption by the kidneys and intestines

Under normal physiological conditions, calcitonin is more important in young individuals (compared to adults), and it may play a role in skeletal development.

In addition, it may protect the bones of the mother from excess calcium loss during pregnancy. Bone formation in the infant and lactation are major drains on Ca 2+ stores. They would cause bone loss in the mother if bone resorption were not simultaneously inhibited by an increase in the plasma calcitonin level.

questions.text: Insulin acts on glucose metabolism by______

choices.text: ↓ permeability of glucose across cell membrane
↑ reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules

questions.solution:
Insulin stimulates the glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane.

This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues.

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by______
questions.solution:
The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch induced by the opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. 

The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance.

This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced injury.

Autoregulation has two main mechanisms:

  • Metabolic mechanism: Tissues produce vasodilatory metabolites that regulate flow e.g. prostaglandins, NO, CO2, H+ and K+
  • Myogenic mechanism

questions.text: A patient who got into an accident is brought to the casualty and is bleeding from his right leg. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Which of the following plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in this patient?
questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin system plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in this patient as the patient has hypovolemia due to blood loss. (refer to figure)

The plasma concentration of renin is the rate-limiting step in the renin-angiotensin system; it is the major determinant of plasma angiotensin II concentration.

Angiotensin II stimulates the aldosterone and ADH secretion; it also constricts the blood vessels and causes thirst, which helps in maintaining blood pressure.

questions.text: From base to the apex of the lung during standing, all the following decrease except ______

choices.text: Intrapleural pressure (with respect to atmospheric pressure)

questions.solution:
V/Q ratio does not decrease from the base to apex of the lung while standing.

  • Normal differences in ventilation and perfusion of the lung in the upright position (refer figure).

Blood flow distribution in the lung

Zones of lung Blood flow Pressure driving blood flow
Zone 1 (near Apex) Lowest  PA > Pa > Pv
Zone 2 Medium Pa > PA > Pv
Zone 3  Highest  Pa > Pv > PA

PA: Alveolar pressure
Pa: arterial pressure
PV: venous pressure

Ventilation–perfusion ratio is not the same in all part of the lungs because of the effect of gravity.

At the apex (Against gravity):

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity. But, a decrease in perfusion is higher than the decrease in ventilation. Hence, ratio increases (3.2).

At the base of lung:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity. Increase in perfusion is more than increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, ratio decreases to 0.6.

The average value of V/Q ratio throughout lungs is 0.8.

Important points:

  • If the effect of gravity is eliminated, as in the supine position, the value is the same in all parts of the lung = 0.8.
  • V/Q ratio is infinity when perfusion is zero as in case of pulmonary embolism.
  • V/Q ratio is zero when ventilation is zero like in case of foreign body obstruction.
  • High V/Q ratio at apex leads to high pAO2 which favors the growth of microorganisms like tubercle bacilli.

Intra-pleural pressure decreases as we move from the base to the apex of the lung i.e- becomes more negative as we move from the base to the apex of the lung.

questions.text: The order of depolarization after stimulation of Purkinje fibers is:
questions.solution:
The order of depolarization is from septum → endocardium→ epicardium.

The spread of Cardiac Excitation:

Atrial depolarization is initiated from SA node spreads radially through atria, then converges on the AV node. A delay of about 0.1s (AV nodal delay) occurs before excitation spreads to the ventricles.
Ventricular depolarization starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to the right across the midportion of the septum. It moves along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface.

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, the opening of the aortic valve takes place at the ______
questions.solution:
Opening of the aortic valve takes place at the end of the isovolumetric contraction.

When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary valves) open, and ventricular ejection begins.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.

Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.

Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus?
questions.solution:
Glomerular mesangial cells are not a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. 

Juxtaglomerular apparatus contains:

  • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle forms the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. 
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, that secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

Note: The distal convoluted tubule starts at the macula densa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady has regular, infrequent menstrual cycles occurring at an interval of 35-36 days. What is the usual timing of ovulation in this lady?
questions.solution:
Ovulation occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length.

If we calculate the day of menstruation from the beginning of the cycle, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14 and in a 35-day cycle, ovulation will occur on day 22.

Option B: LH surge leads to ovulation. Ovulation does not occur before LH surge.

Option C: The ruptured ovarian follicle (after ovulation) is converted into corpus luteum. Ovulation does not occur after corpus luteal maturation.

Option D: Ovulation will occur 14 days before menstruation, i.e. on day 22 of a 35-day cycle. It does not occur 22 days before menstruation.

questions.text: The presence of hemoglobin in normal arterial blood increases its O2 concentration approximately by how many times?
questions.solution:
The presence of hemoglobin in normal arterial blood increases its O2 concentration approximately by 70 times

  • Normal arterial blood has Po2 of about 100 mm Hg.

Amount of O2 transported in dissolved form (Calculated by using Henry's law):

  • Concentration of dissolved O2 = Partial pressure of O2 × solubility of O2 = 100 mmHg × 0.003 mL O2/100 mL blood per mm Hg = 0.3 mL O2/100 mL
  • Hence 1L of plasma has 3mL of 02 in dissolved form.
  • 5L of plasma can carry maximum 15mL of 02.
  • At rest, O2 demand is around 250mL/min. 
  • Hence dissolved O2 alone is not sufficient to meet body demands.

Amount of O2 transported bound to Hb:

  • Concentration of Hb is 15g/100 mL
  • Each gram of Hb binds to 1.34 mL of O2
  • Hence, 15 g binds to 20.1mL of O2/100 mL
  • On average, the 15 g of hemoglobin in 100 mL of blood can combine with a total of about 20 mL of O2.

Thus, this value (20.1) in the presence of Hb is about 70 times the value (0.3) in the absence of Hb.

questions.text: Primary active transport is mediated by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
In active transport the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence many carrier molecules are ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP.

PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT
Requires direct input of metabolic energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)   The transport of two or more solutes is coupled and metabolic energy is provided  indirectly from the Na+ gradient that is maintained across cell membranes by Na+-K+-ATPase pump

a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium potassium pump

b) Ca2+ -ATPase

c) H+-ATPase or proton pump d)      H+-K+-ATPase

a) Na+- glucose cotransport

b) Na+-Ca2+ counter transport

questions.text: A nurse in the pulmonology clinic administered a test using the following instrument. Which of the following parameters cannot be measured?
questions.solution:
The given image shows spirometry. All of the given parameters can be measured by a spirometer except residual volume.

Residual volume is measured by:

  • N2 washout method
  • Helium-dilution method
  • Body plethysmography

Other parameters which cannot be measured by spirometry are:

  • Functional residual capacity
  • Total lung capacity

questions.text: In micturition reflex, the first change to occur is_____
questions.solution:
• One of the initial events is the relaxation of the muscles of the pelvic floor, and this may cause a sufficient downward tug on the detrusor muscle to initiate its contrac­tion.
  • Micturition Reflex
  • Micturition is fundamentally a spinal reflex facili­tated and inhibited by higher brain centers and is subject to voluntary facilitation and inhibition.
  • These centers include
    • strong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pons
    • several centers located in the cerebral cortex that is mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory.
  • The micturition reflex is the basic cause of micturition, but the higher centers normally exert final control of micturition.
  • Micturition Reflex is the result of a stretch reflex initiated by sensory stretch receptors in the bladder wall, especially by the receptors in the posterior urethra when this area begins to fill with urine at the higher bladder pressures.
  • Sensory signals from the bladder stretch receptors are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then reflexively back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers by way of these same nerves. (refer figure)
  • As the bladder continues to fill, the micturition reflexes become more frequent and cause greater contractions of the detrusor muscle.
  • Once a micturition reflex begins, it is “self-regenerative.”
  • It is a single complete cycle of
    • The progressive and rapid increase of pressure,
    • A period of sustained pressure, and
    • Return of the pressure to the basal tone of the bladder.
  • As the bladder becomes more and more filled, micturition reflexes occur more and more often and more and more powerfully.
  • Once the micturition reflex becomes powerful enough, it causes another reflex, which passes through the pudendal nerves to the external sphincter to inhibit it. If this inhibition is more potent in the brain than the voluntary constrictor signals to the external sphincter, urination will occur. If not, urination will not occur until the bladder fills still further and the micturition reflex becomes more powerful.

questions.text: In NREM sleep, which part of brain is not involved?
questions.solution:
The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the Raphe nuclei of ARAS is rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce arousal. Thus, the dorsal raphe nucleus is not involved in NREM sleep.

Genesis and Regulation of NREM sleep

  • Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons called the NREM-on cells.
    • These cells are thought to produce sleep by inhibiting the histaminergic cells in the posterior hypothalamus as well as cells of the nucleus reticularis pontis oralis in the midbrain that mediate arousal.
    • They are maximally active in NREM sleep and inactive during waking and REM sleep.
  • NREM sleep is produced by synchronized synaptic potentials in cortical neurons generated by the rhythmic firing of thalamic relay neurons that project to the cortex. (Thalamocortical loop)

questions.text: Efferent from cerebellar cortex is through which cell:
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are the only output neurons (efferent neurons) from the cerebellar cortex.

The Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellum. Their axons, which are the only output from the cerebellar cortex, project to the deep cerebellar nuclei, especially the dentate nucleus, where they form inhibitory synapses.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding sensory receptor properties?

choices.text: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the intensity of the stimulus
A touch receptor will generate a constant rate of discharge of its axon for as long as the receptor is stimulated
Meissner’s and Pacinian corpuscles adapt slowly, the others adapt rapidly
The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the stimulus given to its receptor

questions.solution:
The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the stimulus given to its receptor.

Intensity of stimulus applied to a sensory receptor can be determined by the following:

  • Variation in frequency of action potentials generated 
  • Variations in the number of receptors activated 

Option A : Weber-Fechner Law states that magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.

Option B: A touch receptor will not generate a constant rate of discharge, even if the receptor is continuously stimulated. This is called desensitization or adaptation. If the opposite were true (if option B was correct), when we have our clothes on, we would have constant firing of neurons unnecessarily, in response to touch stimulus.

Option C:

Slow adapting (Tonic receptors)  Rapidly adapting (Phasic receptors) 
Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs   Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: The correct formula is______
questions.solution:
GFR = Kf ×Net filtration pressure

  • Kf → Filtration coefficient
  • The net filtration pressure is 10 mm Hg ( Note: This is the average net filtration pressure )
  • Thus, GFR= Kf x 10

Filtration Coefficient

  • The Kf is a measure of the product of the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries.
  • The Kf cannot be measured directly, but it is estimated experimentally by dividing the rate of glomerular filtration by net filtration pressure:
  • Because the total GFR for both kidneys is about 125 ml/min and the net filtration pressure is 10 mm Hg, the normal Kf is calculated to be about 12.5 ml/min/ mm Hg of filtration pressure.
  • Some diseases lower Kf by reducing the number of functional glomerular capillaries (thereby reducing the surface area for filtration) or by increasing the thickness of the glomerular capillary membrane and reducing its hydraulic conductivity.
    • Uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus gradually reduce Kf by increasing the thickness of the glomerular capillary basement membrane and, eventually, by damaging the capillaries so severely that there is the loss of capillary function.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about free water clearance?
questions.solution:
Free water clearance is regulated by ADH.

Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, either when dilute urine or when concentrated urine is formed.

Free-water clearance is positive, when excess water is being excreted (dilute urine).

Free-water clearance is negative, when excess solutes are being removed and water is being conserved (concentrated urine).

questions.text: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of______
questions.solution:
Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts.

The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine (terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day.

The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.

questions.text: Normal pH of human semen is_____
questions.solution:
The normal pH of human semen is 7.4 (isotonic).

The pH in the lumen of the epididymis is relatively acidic (6.5 to 6.8) as the result of H+ secretion by clear cells that are analogous to intercalated cells in the nephron. Addition of the relatively alkaline secretions of the seminal vesicles raises the final pH of seminal plasma to between 7.2 and 7.8.

Spermatozoa generally tolerate alkalinity better than acidity.

A pH near neutrality or slightly higher is optimal for the motility and survival of sperm cells in humans and in other species as well.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the mechanism behind an increase in LH secretion just before ovulation ?
questions.solution:
Increased luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion just before ovulation is due to positive feedback by estrogen. 

Phases

Hormone

Type of feedback

Site

FSH and LH secretion

Follicular

Estrogen

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Both suppressed

Midcycle

Estrogen

Positive

Anterior pituitary

Increased LH surge

Luteal

Estrogen

Progesterone

Negative

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Anterior pituitary

Both are decreased

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady undergoes thyroidectomy due to suspected malignancy. A week after the surgery she develops a spasm of facial muscles on tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus. Which of the following is the reason behind her muscle hyperexcitability?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chvostek sign, seen in hypocalcemia due to accidental parathyroid injury during thyroid surgery. The muscle hyperexcitability seen in hypocalcemia is due to increased permeability of cells to Na+. 

During thyroid surgery, parathyroid gland is prone to accidental injury due to proximity with the thyroid gland. Damage to the parathyroid gland will lead to a low PTH level and low Ca2+ level. When the ECF concentration of Ca2+ falls below normal, the nervous system becomes progressively more excitable. Because there is increased membrane permeability to Na+. This leads to easy initiation of the action potentials. 

The peripheral nerve fibres become so excitable that they begin to discharge spontaneously, initiating impulses that pass to the skeletal muscles to elicit tetanic muscle contraction. Tetany occurs usually when calcium concentration falls to 6 mg/dL.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is admitted with nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. On evaluation, he is hypotensive and has mucosal hyperpigmentation. Laboratory workup reveals the diagnosis of hypoaldosteronism. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with hypoaldosteronism, alkalosis is least likely to be found. Hypoaldosteronism is rather responsible for causing metabolic acidosis.

Patients with hypoaldosteronism have:

  • Hyponatremia- due to increased Na+ loss in urine 
  • Hyperkalemia- due to K+ retention 
  • Hypotension- due to reduced ECF volume 
  • Mild metabolic acidosis because hydrogen ions are not secreted in the urine

questions.text: Increased calcium levels lead to______
questions.solution:
Increased calcium levels lead to an increase in 24,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol. 

The levels of calcium control formation of 1,25-dihydroxyxholecalciferol. When calcium is low, PTH (parathyroid hormone) promotes the conversion of 25­hydroxycholecalcif­erol to 1,25­dihydroxycholecalciferol in the kidneys. At higher calcium concentrations, when PTH is sup­pressed, the 25­hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to a different compound—24,25­dihydroxycholecalciferol— that has almost no vitamin D effect.

questions.text: Which of the following increases insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Arginine increases insulin secretion.

Option B: β-adrenergic blockers like propranolol inhibits insulin secretion.

Option C: Epinephrine both stimulates (by beta-adrenergic agonistic action) and inhibits (by alpha-adrenergic agonistic action) the secretion of insulin. However, the inhibitory effect of epinephrine is more dominant than the stimulatory effect.

Option D: Insulin promotes glucose uptake by cells, causing reduced serum K+. Low serum K+ does not cause an increase in insulin secretion. 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting insulin secretion

Stimulators Inhibitors

Glucose

Mannose

2-Deoxyglucose

Mannoheptulose

Glucagon

 Somatostatin 

Amino acids - leucine arginine

Intestinal hormones - GIP, GLP-1, gastrin, secretin, CCK

 K+ depletion 
 

 

Leptin

 

Acetylcholine (Parasympathetic stimulation )

  

β-adrenergic stimulators

Theophylline

Sulfonylureas

α-adrenergic stimulators (norepinephrine, epinephrine)β-Adrenergic blockers  (propranolol)

Diazoxide

Thiazide diuretics

Phenytoin 

Alloxan

Microtubule inhibitors ( Taxanes, Vinca alkaloids)

Insulin

questions.text: All of the following statements about Hering-Breuer inflation reflex are true except_____

choices.text: The impulses travel to the brain via vagus nerve
It results in further inspiratory efforts if the lung is maintained inflated
It is seen in adults at high tidal volumes
Abolishing the reflex in many animals causes slow deep breathing

questions.solution:
Hering-Breuer inflation reflex inhibits further inspiratory efforts if the lungs are maintained inflated.

Mechanism- Stretch receptors ⇒ Vagus ⇒ Inhibit Dorsal Respiratory Group ⇒ Phrenic & Intercostal Nerves ⇒ Inspiration shortened, Expiration prolonged

Option a: The impulses travel to the brain via the vagus nerve.

Option c: HB Reflex activated when TV > 1.5L. The reflex is seen in adults at high tidal volumes.

Option d: Abolishing the reflex by cutting the vagal nerves in experimental animals causes slow deep breathing.

questions.text: The P wave is absent in ___.
questions.solution:
The P wave is absent in atrial fibrillation.

In atrial fibrillation, numerous small depolarization waves spread in all directions through the atria. The waves are weak and many of them are of opposite polarity at any given time, they almost electrically neutralize one another. Therefore, P waves are absent from ECG in atrial fibrillation.
